sen.j: 代官（だいかん）とは、君主(国家)の代わり任地の行政・作事などを司る職務を司った者及びその地位をいう。
sen.e: A daikan (local governor) meant a person whose function was to perform the public administration and construction in a designated territory on behalf of his monarch (state), and daikan also meant his rank itself.

sen.e: A daikan (local governor) meant a person, who performed the public administration and construction in a designated territory on behalf of his monarch (state), and his rank.

sen.e: A local governor enforcing the king's will in western countries was sometimes translated into Japanese as a daikan, but if a governor was so translated, in many cases,he was a villain like the one in a William Tell or a Robin Hood play, this being most likely due to the effect from Japanese period dramas.

sen.j: 中世以降の日本では、預所代、国司の目代、守護代、小守護代、地頭代、或いは出征した軍勢の統括を代行する陣代などの代官職があり、さらにそれらの代官である叉代というのもあった。
sen.e: After the medieval period in Japan, there were many deputy posts like azukaridokorodai (acting deputy shoen lord; shoen was a manor), kokushi no mokudai (deputy kokuhsi; kokushi was a provincial governor mostly before the Muromachi period), shugodai (deputy shugo: shugo was a military governor), koshugodai (acting deputy military governor), jitodai (deputy jito; jito was a shoen steward), and jindai whose function was to preside troops on a campaign as a deputy, and furthermore, there existed a deputy post of these deputies called matadai (literally, "double deputy").

sen.j: 平安時代以降、国司自ら着任することなく国府の政務を代行を遙任された遙任という制度が確立し、遙任をした国司より国府に目代という地位が置かれることが一般的となった。
sen.e: After the Heian period, a yonin (remote appointments) practice became common, in which kokushi did not reside in his appointed province but privately selected a person to attend the governance of the province on his behalf, and it became popular for kokushi who adopted this practice to set up a post called mokudai (deputy kokushi) in kokufu (provincial office).
sen.cmt: 原文は「平安時代以降、国司自ら着任することなく国府の政務を代行を遙任された遙任という制度が確立し、遙任をした国司より国府に目代という地位が置かれることが一般的となった。」となっています。この文章の前半は意味がとりづらいのですが、「平安時代以降、国司自ら着任することなく（目代が）国府の政務（を）代行を遙任された遙任という制度が確立し、」と解釈し翻訳しました。
sen.e: After the Heian period, yonin system (remote appointments), which kokushi did not reside in his appointed province but his deputy attended the governance of the province on his behalf, was established, and it became popular for kokushi who adopted this system to set up the deputy post called mokudai (deputy kokushi) in kokufu (provincial office).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以降、守護地頭制に基づく武家政権の土地支配の権力構造が成立すると、複数の諸国に守護職を得た御家人が守護代を置くようになり、守護の職権を代行した。
sen.e: After the Kamakura period, with the establishment of a power structure concerning land ruling based on a shugo jito system (system to govern provinces by military governors and their estate stewards) in the samurai government, gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogunate) who were assigned to multiple shugo posts in several provinces came to privately appoint shugodai (deputy shugo), who performed the shugo roll on behalf of shugo.

sen.j: 室町時代においては幕府直轄領の管理者が代官と称され、守護の代官たる守護代やその代官たる小守護代などとは区別された（守護代の項目参照）。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the administrators of lands under direct control of bakufu (the shogunate) were called daikan, and they were distinguished from shugodai who performed the deputy roll of shugo, and from koshugodai who were deputies of shugodai. (See Shugodai for details).

sen.j: このように、広義における代官職は国司の目代や守護代のように、任国の職務を代行する地位を広く指したが、室町時代以降となると、当初は室町幕府の直轄領地の支配を代行する地位を指すようになり、これに習い、戦国大名たちも自身の直轄領に代官を置くようになったことから代官を職名とする地位全般を指すようになった。
sen.e: In a broad sense, as explained above, the post of daikan extensively meant a deputy post, of which roll was to attend the duty in an appointed province like the post of mokudai (deputy kokushi) and shugodai (deputy shugo); but after the Muromachi period, daikan post came to mean, originally, a post which attended the rulings of lands under direct control of the Muromachi bakufu (Muromachi shogunate) on behalf of it, and later in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) followed this practice, appointing their own daikan in lands under their direct control, thus the title of daikan came to represent not only being a deputy but rather the post as a whole under that title.

sen.j: 特に安土桃山時代以降は織田信長が自身の家中において家臣を城下に居住させることを徹底し、領主不在の領地が急激に増えたこともあり、家臣の新知の知行地もまとめて代官に管理させるようにした。
sen.e: After the Azuchi-Momoyama Period in particular, as Nobunaga ODA forced his vassals in his clan to live in ODA's castle town without exception, which resulted in a rapid increase in demesnes without their lords residing there, thus it became a practice to let daikan administer their demesnes including newly enfeoffed lands.

sen.e: In the Edo period, daikan as well as gundai (daikan administering relatively wide shogunal lands) were appointed by the bakufu (shogunet) under the control of kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), and they administered the enfeoffed lands of small sized hatamoto (direct retainers of the Edo bakufu) and tenryo (shogunal lands; the name tenryo was used after Meiji ear).
